Hey Ken; 

Go easy on poor Milt, I like buying his tsuba makes great ballast in the bilge of the sail boat.

John
  ----- Original Message ----- 
  From: Kenneth Wilson 
  To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com 
  Sent: Friday, December 23, 2005 9:13 AM
  Subject: RE: [nihontostudy] Where do you buy your Tsuba?


  Mark,

  I don't travel, just send me the lobster and bear
  eh?!!  I'm sure you can always find someone to sell
  you stuff... Good and Bad.

  Milt, I forgot....you must follow the most important
  rule...."Don't get high on your own supply"!!!!.....I
  thought you weren't from this world.  Off to the
  in-laws.............

  Merry commercialism.

  Ken


  --- Andres Pedraza <apedraza@...> wrote:

  > Mark,
  > 
  > If the Andres you refer to is me, I'm as New Yorker
  > as they come, not 
  > international at all. I work in Manhattan and live
  > in the Poconos. :)
  > 
  > Beer and lobster sounds great. Just pick a date...
  > I've always meant 
  > to go take a look at New Brunswick, especially Fundy
  > Bay. Heard good 
  > stuff about it.
  > 
  > If you didn't mean me, then too late, I'm still
  > going.
  > 
  > Dewa,
  > 
  > Andres
  > 
  > At 08:52 AM 12/23/2005, you wrote:
  > >Hi John,
  > >              Has Christmas come early?!  I could
  > have sworn it was only
  > >friday!
  > >You're telling me you know of contacts in Canada
  > for study and collection?
  > >Well Merry Christmas to me!  LOL
  > >I live in New Brunswick on the east coast.
  > Occasionally I'll make it out
  > >west to do some mountain climbing and I've been
  > down to New Hampshire, Mount
  > >Washington. Apart from that, I usually don't get
  > state side. I can just see
  > >myself trying to explain to a customs officer that
  > I'm travelling to the
  > >U.S. to attend a Japanese Sword Show! LOL! I'm
  > going to need a passport next
  > >year just to cross the border into Maine so I can
  > buy cheap milk!
  > >Where abouts  are you located John?
  > >Any information you can provide me with would be
  > greatly appreciated. If
  > >anyone out there in Nihonto land wants to come to
  > New Brunswick and share
  > >their knowledge, I will supply Beer and Lobsters.
  > >Now if there's going to be more than 10 of you or
  > any international
  > >arrivals, (Andres), I will need some time to plan.
  > >Have a great holiday season everyone. It's been
  > great listening to your
  > >banter.
  > >
  > >Mark
  > >
  > >
  > >-----Original Message-----
  > >From: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
  > >[mailto:nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com]On Behalf Of
  > John Berta
  > >Sent: Thursday, December 22, 2005 5:53 PM
  > >To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
  > >Subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Where do you buy your
  > Tsuba?
  > >
  > >
  > >Hi Mark;
  > >
  > >Where in Canada are you.  There are some very good
  > study groups in Canada
  > >and opportunity to learn and collect swords and
  > fittings.
  > >
  > >John
  > >----- Original Message -----
  > >From: "Mark Jaillet" <mjaillet@...>
  > >To: <nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com>
  > >Sent: Thursday, December 22, 2005 12:22 PM
  > >Subject: RE: [nihontostudy] Where do you buy your
  > Tsuba?
  > >
  > >
  > >Hi Ron,
  > >Anthony should try collecting up here in Canada!
  > Now THAT
  > >is a challenge. I for one would be more than
  > interested to know what you
  > >have to offer and suggestions would be more than
  > appreciated. I'd be more
  > >than happy to [ay in "lobster" or "hockey skates"!
  > LOL!!!!
  > >
  > >Kind regards, Mark
  > >
  > >
  > >
  > >-----Original Message-----
  > >From: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
  > [mailto:nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com]On
  > >Behalf Of Ron Hartmann
  > >Sent: Wednesday, December 21, 2005 10:04 PM
  > >To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
  > >Subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Where do you buy your
  > Tsuba?
  > >
  > >
  > >Anthony -
  > >
  > >Sorry to sound like such a "merchant" but if you're
  > interested I can send
  > >you some pictures of a very nice selection of good
  > quality iron tsuba that
  > >I'm selling. Most are $200 range, more or less. If
  > you are new at this I
  > >would be happy to recommend good ones that would
  > help teach you about these
  > >things. Some of these have been to a number of
  > shows and are now kept home
  > >so that I can keep my table at the shows, fresh.
  > All are authentic, for
  > >sure. The shows seem to have a wonderful selection
  > of nice quality tsuba
  > >these days and that is good for the buyer, bad for
  > the seller since there is
  > >such a "selection" to pick from. Anyway...just
  > thought I'd toss this idea
  > >out to you. I've been around for going on 40
  > years...gosh, that's a little
  > >frightening to put in writing!
  > >
  > >Ron
  > >STL
  > >----- Original Message -----
  > >From: anwahi
  > >To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
  > >Sent: Wednesday, December 21, 2005 4:23 PM
  > >Subject: [nihontostudy] Where do you buy your
  > Tsuba?
  > >
  > >
  > >Hello,
  > >
  > >I'm new here and to collecting Tsuba. Where do you
  > buy your Tsuba from?
  > >I know there's several websites you can find with a
  > Google search, an
  > >occasional Token Kai show like the one in SF, or
  > Ebay (most look like
  > >junk). I'm looking for good sources of authentic
  > Tsuba. Obviously the
  > >only way to be really sure of authenticity is to
  > purchase papered
  > >Tsuba, but because I'm starting off I want some
  > sources of authentic
  > >Tsuba more reasonably priced. Any suggestions?
  > >
  > >Thanks for your helpo in advance,
  > >Anthony
  > >
  > >
  > >
  > >
  > >
